worklogs.comment:
jcrist opened a new pull request #2394: ARROW-3009: [Python] Fix pyarrow ORC reader
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2394
 
 
   This errored on master due to the removal of `RecordBatch.__init__` from
   public api. Replaced with equivalent function. Have tested that this
   works fine locally - can't test in arrow until test infrastructure for
   ORC is setup.

jcrist commented on issue #2394: ARROW-3009: [Python] Fix pyarrow ORC reader
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2394#issuecomment-411197090
 
 
   > I'd be surprised if it took more than a day of work (or less) to make one
   
   Maybe. My experience building the reader was that the ORC library needed a ton of work to make the cmake build usable in another project. There may be similar things to make the writer usable.
   
   In any case, I think this PR should be good to merge, a writer/tests should be a subsequent PR.

wesm closed pull request #2394: ARROW-3009: [Python] Fix pyarrow ORC reader
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2394
 
 
   

This is a PR merged from a forked repository.
As GitHub hides the original diff on merge, it is displayed below for
the sake of provenance:

As this is a foreign pull request (from a fork), the diff is supplied
below (as it won't show otherwise due to GitHub magic):

diff --git a/python/pyarrow/_orc.pyx b/python/pyarrow/_orc.pyx
index c95bea2834..9493f2327d 100644
--- a/python/pyarrow/_orc.pyx
+++ b/python/pyarrow/_orc.pyx
@@ -26,6 +26,7 @@ from pyarrow.includes.libarrow cimport *
 from pyarrow.lib cimport (check_status,
                           MemoryPool, maybe_unbox_memory_pool,
                           Schema, pyarrow_wrap_schema,
+                          pyarrow_wrap_batch,
                           RecordBatch,
                           pyarrow_wrap_table,
                           get_reader)
@@ -93,9 +94,7 @@ cdef class ORCReader:
                 (check_status(deref(self.reader)
                               .ReadStripe(stripe, indices, &sp_record_batch)))
 
-        batch = RecordBatch()
-        batch.init(sp_record_batch)
-        return batch
+        return pyarrow_wrap_batch(sp_record_batch)
 
     def read(self, include_indices=None):
         cdef:

fields.description:
This is probably because there no tests for the python orc reader (sorry I never got around to that).

The error message is

TypeError: Do not call RecordBatch's constructor directly, use one of the `RecordBatch.from_*` functions instead.

and comes from these lines in the orc cython code: https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/python/pyarrow/_orc.pyx#L96-L97

I'm not sure what they should be replaced with in the new api.
fields.summary: [Python] pyarrow.orc uses APIs now prohibited in 0.10.0

comments.body: Looks like it should be `pyarrow_wrap_batch`. Will issue a PR.

That's a bummer. I will ask ASF infra to create a git repo where we can stash testing datasets since I'm against checking in binary files into mainline git if it can be avoided. Do you have applications that use this code that can be run regularly against the master branch?

We run tests in the dask repository pulling one of the test datasets distributed in the orc repo from github using requests. This is ok, but not optimal (really just a smoketest). I currently don't have any applications running this code, but once a way to get a few datasets for arrow is determined, writing the tests shouldn't be too difficult.
ORC supports writing files now in C++, right? Adding a minimal solution to write files (to round-trip data like we are doing in the Parquet tests) would be the ideal solution

It did when I did the initial writeup as well. The issue is the writer doesn't support nearly as many features as the reader. In particular, it can only write HIVE 0.11 format, which is rather old (2013!) and doesn't support decimals with precision/scale. It would be better than nothing though.

Personally I think using the datasets from the ORC repo, or generating our own using an external tool would be an easier way to move forward immediately.
